Certainly! John Constable was deeply interested in capturing the beauty of nature, and he believed that light and color were essential components of the landscape. He once wrote, "The landscape painter must walk in the fields with a humble mind. No arrogant man was ever permitted to see Nature in all her beauty." Constable believed that by capturing the effect of light and color on the landscape, he could create a more authentic and honest depiction of nature.

Additionally, one of Constable's goals was to challenge traditional notions of landscape painting. In the past, landscapes had been seen as background settings, without much attention paid to their details. Constable sought to revolutionize this tradition by elevating the landscape to the forefront of his paintings and by carefully observing and capturing its nuances.

In short, Constable's focus on light and color was a way for him to create a more honest and authentic portrayal of nature, and it also allowed him to challenge traditional approaches to landscape painting.
